Okay. Thanks, Richard.
Thanks, David.
Your next question today comes from the line of Craig Woolford from Citi. Craig, please go ahead.

Good afternoon, Richard and Terry. Just wanted to ask a question about the food and liquor business, you said looking at 2% space growth going forward. If my math is right that's about 15 stores. How did you come out with that number and does the company consider protecting its turf a reason to open stores if there is a rival retailer that may want to open an attachment, but the return on capital doesn't stack up?

I think what we've maintained a fairly consistent approach towards space, Craig, and we talk more about in space stores rather than absolute number of stores. The stores we've been opening have been roughly 50% bigger than the ones we have been closing. So as I mentioned that in the presentation, the number that we closed is pretty similar to the ones that we've opened, but obviously the space growth there, Net 6% since we started the transformation. And we're looking at sort of between 2% to 3% of space growth over the next, the next few years, is really what I'd estimate coming out at. We've got a return on capital requirements. We want to make sure that we focus on quality of space, not quantity of stores. And that's served us well in the past and it will serve us well in the future.
Yeah. So the – is it 2% to 3% or...

Well, it be somewhere within there. It varies depending on, you cannot really be that precise about it, it's a guide because you don't know when deals are ultimately going to be done and when actually does the stores are physically open, they can flip over from half into the next or one year into the next. But broadly, as a guide, that's what we would expect along the line.

Craig, I'm not aware of any new store in retail, I'm only – actually in my history at Wesfarmers, aware of once we've approved a capital expenditure below our hurdle rate. And that time was when I was running our Rural Services division and we had to build some cattle yards which we knew wouldn't going to make any sense, but if we didn't we were going to exit the cattle industry. I'm not aware of any instance where we've approved based on our forecasts, CapEx on a new store below our hurdle rate and cost of capital.
Sure, though, but...
And we wouldn't do it for defensive reasons, because that's just a recipe for disaster.
Yeah, okay. As long as other rates have the final price, I guess. (1:21:36)
Well it may not.

Yeah. My other question was around wage pressures. From what I read of the ABI agreements on Bunnings and Kmart, there probably is some wage pressures coming as they have to move towards the General Retail Award on Sunday loading and overtime.
Could you just talk to whether that is a pressure that the company faces and how they (1:22:03)?

I'll let John kick off in a second, Craig, but I was asked this at a press conference a little bit earlier, I don't think there's much difference at the moment. We've got ABIs on the go all the time in different parts of the business. We settled Curragh last year and you might remember when we did Curragh, there was actually a lot going on. BMA had a long dispute and we're able to settle our arrangements in Curragh very quickly. We've got a terrific workforce at Curragh . And my assessment at the moment is not much had changed on this front, there's always a robust negotiations at an ABI level, but I wouldn't say from where I'm sitting that there's an increase in expectations above what we've been saying. John, Dene anyone else want to comment?

Hi, It's Richard. From a Bunnings point of view and from Officeworks point of view, your comments are very well founded. And Craig I'm not sure what information you're looking at because it doesn't accord with our thinking with the right sorts of pressures and particularly relevant to the way we've structured our ABI. We've have very, very high retention amongst our permanent team, the ABI covers – we have in place covers from earnings point of view, a huge number of our team across Australia, and what we know that they're happy and we'll look to reward them in lots of different ways and those sorts of pressures just aren't relevant for us.
Okay. So just a technical one around the Sunday loading rights having to match the General Retail Award?

Yeah. There's lots of intricacies in Fair Work Craig, and we've managed to have some very good discussions. The first time we went through the Fair Work process where those issues were understood against the balance of all the things we do around weekends, public holidays and the way that we gauge and remunerate our team.
Thank you.
Your next question today comes from the line of Daniel Broeren from CIMB. Daniel, please go ahead.

Thank you, good afternoon. My questions relate to the Coles Express and specifically the recent price caps. To my understanding is up to 100 products are now priced in line with supermarket pricing, so given the cost to operate a convenience store are relatively high compared to a supermarket, can you please talk about the sustainability of having the same prices but with different cost basis? And just the second question is given that a large number of Express customers would be Coles docket shoppers, would the impact of any volume growth in Express have more impact on Coles' supermarkets rather than competitors?

I don't think so, I think that as far as pricing is concerned, that the two areas operate independently and clearly with shop sales looking to try and see if we can improve upon them, we're looking at the relative competitiveness. But they operate independently. The biggest impact, I guess, is a more of a high profile lines where we reduced the price of bread and milk into alignment with the Down Down products that we've done as well. So we've looked at that quite specifically. But I thought it was going to be an adverse impact in terms of our sales growth in supermarkets as a result of actions taken in the convenience chain.
Is it fair to say or is it possible for you to say that the bread and milk categories within Coles Express are profitable on a standalone basis?

Well, in our world, we actually wouldn't be doing something that we didn't think we could actually believe we can get a fixed return from it (1:25:25). So we've aligned the pricing. It's consistent with what we're doing in other aspects of Express as well. It's an area that's obviously quite profiled in relation to the – what the consumer sees as well, and we recognize that as well but we're happy with the profitability that we're generating out of Coles Express, both in terms of fewer line shop sales. And we'll aim look to see if we can improve the shop sales from where they are currently.
Okay. Thank you.
Your next question today comes from the line of Phillip Kimber from Goldman Sachs. Phillip, please go ahead.

Hi, guys. I'm just wondering if you could talk a little bit about sales trends you've seen since being the end of the financial year? Has there been any noticeable change or are we sort of similar to the trends we saw in the second quarter?

Yeah, Phil. As always, I'm slightly reluctant, but it's worth calling out there's been a bit of government money flowing around in January, obviously, in January and February because of the back-to-school bonus payments, if you like, for kids that the government released. And we've seen some impact of that. And can actually see it by demographics by store, particularly Target and Kmart. Might have been a bit in Officeworks as well.

And the reason we can say is tactually when the checks get released, we can see the impact of store levels. So we know that's had an impact and might have had in some, in those businesses up to 1% improvement in sales through January. So if I leave that to one side, I'd say January, February has been pretty much a continuation maybe in – I don't think there is any reduction in confidence. Maybe a marginal improvement in confidence.
Okay. And then I...

And Ian McLeod's just sort of said, hey, hang on what are you talking about, don't raise expectations. But I just think if you think about it, there's less bad news and marginally more good news around these days. But consumers are being very careful and I think that's where we're at.

And just a clarification question on the resources. I think Stewart mentioned Resources costs are up 11% in the second half. I wasn't sure if he meant on the second half of last year or on the first half of this year?
Costs up, you mean?
I think I just heard him talk in his main part – not an answer to a question. In the main part he mentioned resources costs will be up another 11%, sorry down another 11% in the second half?

That's right. We expect that further costs will come out of our business in the short-term, in the next six months. That'll be another 11%. But it's fair to say looking into FY 2014, we think costs will go up from that bottom, which is about 30% odd down, up by about 10%. And that's basically as a result of consuming, I suppose, work that we've done at Curragh over the last couple of years following the floods in 2011 where we moved a lot of other than the head of active coal phases. (1:28:38)

We've run that other burden advance (1:28:43) down in this current financial year. That's work we've already done ahead of where we should have been. And for next year, we'll see a slight increase of 10%. So that's – so looking at the second half of this year, it'll be a further 11% down. And looking through that reduction process, we'll be up about 10% next year.
Right. And that's on prior year, not on the.....
Yes, that's right. On the prior year.
Your next question today comes from the line of David Thomas from CLSA. David, please go ahead.

Okay. Thank you. Just Richard, really I think this question is probably for you. A lot of your businesses are operating on a pretty even keel now, particularly sort of the retail operations. And obviously, there is perhaps a little bit more today than there has been in the past couple of years. Can you give some areas of thought around that?

Yeah, in a general sense I will, David. I think we probably thought for a year or so that we've got the management capacity now to do something of interest of scale was to arise. I mean, there is lots of things we're looking at, at divisional level and things like that. But, significant for a division but relatively modest for the group. And we'll continue to do that. From a group point of view, though, I think, I do think we've got the capacity financially and management wise. I actually think we've strengthened the capabilities across the group at management levels fairly significantly over the last few years.

So it's a matter of an opportunity or opportunities coming along that make sense to us. And we're always actively looking and thinking about things. We're not going to be rushed into it. We'll be very patient and we'll be very disciplined about anything we may or may not do. Often making any decision not to do something is more important than the decision to do something. So yes, we've got the capacity financially and human resources, it's a matter of the right opportunity coming along otherwise. We've got significant investment going into our businesses. We've still got I think a heck of lot of work to do in all of our businesses to improve how we're operating to provide better outcomes for our customers, to innovate and create new opportunities within each of the businesses. So we'll keep doing what we've been doing and hopefully make a decent return for our shareholders on the way.

Would you extend that to so far as to look internationally? Particularly, obviously Asia obviously is close enough and the success stories out there, at least in our consumer land, have been those that do have an Asian operations. Is there any thought process to international acquisitions?

There is certainly a thought process at both divisional and at the group level. But we've got our eyes wide open every time when we go into those markets, you've got a have a good look of who is playing in there and what you need you to do to be a winner. We've beefed up or we're in the process of beefing up some resources overseas at the moment, which is just improving our connection too. Sure. So, from a profitability point of view, we've made fairly significant investments in our capabilities in personal lines. So the actual contribution to profits is not material, but what we are finding is that the improved capabilities around risk pricing and claims management, particularly through our national repair network, is starting to drive improvements in average claims cost and loss ratio across personal lines in Lumley, WFI and so forth. So that is having a benefit. You're right that the key, the key area of growth in premium is personal lines. And are you finding those new customers sticky?

Yeah, we're quite happy with retention rates and we – just on the personal lines side through Coles we just recently went through the 150,000 policy level and we're looking to move that up because we see opportunities in that space. When you look at industry profitability, Australian private motor insurance, there are quite strong returns being generated in that area. So we think there is an opportunity for our customers to save some money and for us to make decent return going forward.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
Thanks.

Good afternoon, guys. Just another question on Target. We've heard about the revenue impact of the toy sale. And then second, your second question in relation to transformation related expenses, I would say that the first half of fiscal 2013 had very elevated, and in a going forward perspective, one-offset of expenses, and that we have taking steps to reduce the needs for those one-off costs in several ways, which I mentioned in response to a question from David earlier, including making sure that we have got our own internal capabilities that we don't need external management consultants, and other assistance, which tends to be very high cost, as well as having spent money on online platform, and other investments of a similar nature online that will serve us well for the next few years. Your next question comes from the line of David Cooke from Nomura. David, please go ahead.

Hi guys, a couple of questions to Stewart on Resources, if I may. Stewart, just looking at your cost out in the second half of 2013 and increase in 2014, can you give us an indication please as to how much of that cost base is in your control? And how much is dependent on volume growth to fractionalize a fixed cost base. Or conversely if things, if volume comes down, what impact that could have on your ability to pull those costs out?

Look, we are not reliant on c volume increases for next year. We're currently in that 8 million tonnes to 8.5 million tonnes in terms of met coal. Just looking at the cost decreases, of the total decrease in costs, about two-thirds is sustainable long-term with a third not sustainable. So we've come down 20% in the first half, there's a further 11% in the second half. That gives you, I would just add a 30%. We will go up by that 10% in next year. And as I said before, the reason for that going up is that this year we're consuming work we've done in advance from, basically from overburden renewals getting well ahead in terms of truck and shovel, well ahead of where the dry down (1:40:31) operations are.

So this year we are obviously consuming that work we've done in advance, so therefore our costs are lower as a result of that. But when we get into FY 2014, we would have consumed all that work in advance that we've done. So in terms of the total, the cost reductions, two-thirds of that's sustainable.

The thing could suggest, Stewart, that you're trying to make a short-term number look better by not continuing on with the overburden removal and trying to benefit from – in fact mining rather than overburdening now. Is it a mine operational thing or is that a case of you're trying to achieve a short-term cost target?

Well at the moment, we're clearly focused on reducing our costs. The marketplace is pretty tight. You've seen our EBIT numbers. We've done a lot of work in advance of where we should have been and that's directly attributed to basically the major flooding we had in 2011. The difficulty in getting back and operating at full capacity down in the pits, the areas that were dry for operational were truck and shovel pre-strip ahead of drag along (1:41:48). So we got well ahead of our business and we're currently taking advantage of that in this current financial year at a time when obviously coal prices and exchange rates are very difficult.
Okay. Sorry, a clarification question, your hedging profile doesn't look has changed since June, is that correct?

We have sort of backed off putting hedges in place at the moment. Clearly when exchange rates are in the 1.03, 1.04, 1.05, it's very hard to put hedges in place when potentially all the downside is – if you put it into the higher rates and the exchange rate comes off and then clearly you're causing a problem for yourself.
So effectively, you're increasing your proportion of spot sales quite considerably at the moment?
Just say that again.
No, not the steel contract, just hedging. I mean, we have a range of hedging and we're just headed toward the lower end of the range, that's all.
Yeah. That's right.
Okay. Thank you.

And David, I don't think you have to be cynic to ask the question about what we're doing. What we're doing is managing cost of the business, and we got criticized last year for not making enough money. We said at that time, we've actually done a lot overburden removal and because of that work we were doing a commissioning of the new wash plant we're taking advantage of that this year, as Stewart said, in circumstances where we understand conventional pressure of the mine. I think it's just a sensible thing to do.
Okay. Thanks, Richard. And final one from me is the carbon tax, can you give us an update please as to how much that have cost you since this thing is implemented for six months now?
Is that to Resources or...
Sorry, that's across the whole business?

(01:43:35) $100 million or thereabouts. And half a year. That looks in that kind of order. If you look at the key operational impact across the various divisions, you've seen the electricity line office.
So that's in addition, David. So there is a carbon tax impasse that every one of our businesses is incurring higher energy costs at the moment.
Yes. Thanks a lot.
Your next question comes from the line of Greg Dring from Macquarie. Greg, please go ahead.

Thanks. Good afternoon, Ian. You speak quickly, but so do I and that's okay. But I want to make sure I caught what you said about value, around about slide 15 you made this comment. You've actually said that value is not just for the few, but obviously with retail loyalty you've got to give some special reward. And you alluded to the fact that 50% of your transaction volume or value, I'm not sure which one, is on FlyBuys. So I'm just wondering about this whole value platform and how you differentiate it between loyalty and value for the masses if I can use that term?

Well, we look at it as an integrated approach. I think I mentioned this before, Greg. So we're obviously looking at the balance of mix of fewer, stronger promotions, which we've executed as part of our strategy. We've clearly got levels a Down Down price investment to bring prices down and operate more of an EDLP platform when they stay down for prolonged periods. We use fuel discounts as well and then Target Loyalty programs through the dates that we now have available. So those loyalty programs can either be in terms of spend stretch in relation cash or indeed to points or indeed back into fuel. So we'll use all those metrics in order to make sure that we've got the right balance or mix to motivate customers broadly and specifically in terms of spending more at Coles.
So your reference to value not just for a few, I thought you were trying to allude perhaps to the loyalty program and then you didn't have to be a FlyBuys member to get that value?

Yeah, well I think that's – there's not a lot of truth in that. I think that if you're going to establish yourself as a retailer focused on value, you have to make sure that that value is open to all. I think if you're going to try and restrict your level of value investment you're going to make to target a limited number of customers in isolation, then that's probably a strategy we wouldn't support.
But you're roughly 50:50, aren't you, didn't you say 50% of transactions are on FlyBuys?

Yeah. Well 50% of our transactions are on FlyBuys now. So you have opportunities then to look at that particular customer set. But also there's again 50% that aren't. And clearly what we're focused on very much is at improving and growing our overall transactions attracting new customers, not just trying to protect our existing ones.
And then is eth priority to get more FlyBuys members or more customers?
No, I think it would be to get more customers.
Okay.

But clearly, there is a loyalty program out there we reinvigorated last year and as a result of that, we've got more active users of FlyBuys than ever before. But it's a balance in this to make sure that you're giving some offers and deals and value to other customers without excluding others that perhaps haven't got a card.
Okay. Thank you.
Thanks, Greg.
Your next question comes from the line of Shaun Cousins from JPMorgan. Shaun, please go ahead.

Thanks. Just a question in regards to the working capital at retail. Could you talk about which divisions made be the biggest progress this year, pardon me, this half in terms of other working capital out?

In terms of – on a net basis, indiscernible (1:47:29) has made the biggest progress. And we saw good performances from all the other divisions on a like-for-like basis in terms of net working capital days. And obviously, new stores coming down for some divisions more than others. And is Coles comfortable with the level of inventory that they've got in terms of – we understand they tend to run a little richer on inventory relative to Woolworths just in terms of where Coles is at in its broader working cap out program.

Okay. Thanks.
Thanks, Shaun.
